channel.title: 华尔街日报热门
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: The European Union said it has hit its target of fully vaccinating 70% of adults against Covid-19 by the end of summer https://t.co/QJa7Bhvcdh
Two broken MacBooks and quotes from four repair shops help columnist @JoannaStern explain why new “Right to Repair” legislation could save you money and time https://t.co/E2LNBZRcEe

Social Security is expected to pay benefits that exceed its income in 2021 and reserves are expected to be depleted by 2034, one year sooner than previously estimated, trustees said in an annual report https://t.co/MRjr1LHQGd
President Biden is addressing the nation, a day after the U.S. completed its chaotic exit from Afghanistan and ended its longest war. Watch live. https://t.co/RSA1G4s1Rx
Americans are back to buying up toilet paper and paper towels. The maker of Charmin and Bounty is ramping up production, running factories 24 hours a day, seven days a week. https://t.co/5Wm9RqY67s
An exurban boom is transforming the Southeast, as people flock to places like Charlotte, Charleston and Jacksonville https://t.co/8haWrrrUvy

Israel is upping the vaccine ante, pressing citizens to get Covid-19 booster shots and saying those who don’t will face restrictions on traveling, dining out and other activities https://t.co/vPZSpj6EeU
With the troops gone from Afghanistan, the U.S. faces a new security challenge: How to track and kill terrorists without eyes and boots on the ground https://t.co/LBJ2j696lG

“Mr. President...Don’t forget me here.” An Afghan interpreter who 13 years ago helped rescue Joe Biden was left behind Monday when the U.S. ended its military campaign in Afghanistan. https://t.co/9P1MJFA2AW
In nine hours, you could fly from Chicago to Miami three times. One traveler spent that long on hold with an airline's customer service number. https://t.co/ImxNw6EaMD
Two broken MacBooks and quotes from four repair shops help columnist @JoannaStern explain why new “Right to Repair” legislation could save you money and time https://t.co/1Jfw7nVCcJ
One in six home sales went to an investor in the second quarter of 2021, according to Redfin. In Atlanta, Phoenix and Miami, it was one in four. https://t.co/ghEZqYPQPu
From college football to the NFL, more sporting events are requiring fans to show proof of Covid-19 vaccination to get in the door https://t.co/8VB8TWH0TU
From @WSJopinion: Targeting the Taliban’s financial networks is a critical first step to preventing future attacks, write @MatthewZweig1 and @rich_goldberg https://t.co/awWAzQuE4m
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/sf8gs7n1t6 https://t.co/u3B2n6gKsM
Hate crimes in the U.S. last year reached levels not seen in more than a decade, fueled by increases in anti-Asian, anti-Black and antiwhite incidents, new FBI statistics show https://t.co/9gFYRZ6qd3
In a global first, Google and Apple will have to open their app stores to alternative payment systems in South Korea, threatening their commissions https://t.co/ySAs1JSHdq

The Pentagon pledged a transparent investigation of a drone strike in Kabul Sunday aimed at foiling an Islamic State attack. Ten civilians were killed, relatives of the dead said. https://t.co/eeo0F5BbSi
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/LKbxq1jSay https://t.co/YDgaHw3RSt
A $369 cellphone slated to arrive this fall can make calls and send texts, but can't access social media, take photos or send email https://t.co/uuQohHHdYV
Many young professionals, burned out from remote work and equipped with some savings, are quitting their jobs with no firm Plan B https://t.co/ZVGvj2s36f
From a Washington hotel, a group of American civilians plotted a military-style rescue operation that extracted 5,000 Afghans from Kabul https://t.co/PlRk6DTAHd

From @WSJopinion: Stupidity is one of life’s big mysteries, like evil, like love, an ineffable thing. You cannot exactly define it, but you know it when you see it, writes Lance Morrow. https://t.co/Y950FaIDN3
U.S.-trained Afghan pilots who flew to Uzbekistan as the Taliban seized power in Afghanistan are caught in a diplomatic tussle https://t.co/OcUXO7oBuD
Burned out and equipped with savings, some millennials are quitting their jobs with no Plan B https://t.co/Z8iLSsKbhg
China is cracking down on youth videogame addiction: No gaming during the school week and one hour a day on Fridays, weekends and public holidays https://t.co/FceQor9pWY
Breaking: The last U.S. troops flew out of Afghanistan, ending two decades of war. Hundreds of Americans and thousands of Afghans left behind face an uncertain future. https://t.co/FoB6LOe313

From @WSJopinion: If teachers and parents, the two most important groups in education, are uncomfortable with critical race theory, perhaps bureaucrats and elected officials should think seriously before proceeding, writes John Beatty https://t.co/sXriWscjYz
Many young professionals, burned out from remote work and equipped with some savings, are quitting their jobs with no firm Plan B https://t.co/vnuCvjLZ2B

Most children admitted to intensive care with a serious inflammatory complication after getting Covid-19 didn’t have serious lingering issues a year later, according to a study of data collected from hospitals across the U.K. https://t.co/4wymmp433b

Dozens of United Airlines jets like the one that lost an engine cover over Colorado in February will take longer than expected to return to service, as federal regulators weigh additional safeguards https://t.co/EuAbNnBO8X https://t.co/8yNIigklJX
Ida is presenting the biggest test yet of the storm risk-reduction system that was installed in the New Orleans metro area after Hurricane Katrina. https://t.co/kfzLJi8MlO
From a Washington hotel, a group of American civilians plotted a military-style rescue operation that extracted 5,000 Afghans from Kabul https://t.co/ZffT4IoXHM
Krispy Kreme’s CFO plans to focus on paying off debt and delivering fresher doughnuts to grocery and convenience stores https://t.co/Lt1WHy1b3q
U.S.-trained Afghan pilots who flew to Uzbekistan as the Taliban swept to power in Afghanistan are caught in a diplomatic tussle https://t.co/Dy7RKqtZBl
A $369 cellphone slated to arrive this fall can make calls and send texts, but can't access social media, take photos or send email https://t.co/3CIVpQKV4S
From @WSJopinion: The 13 men and women who died in Kabul were on a rescue mission. They represent the best of America, writes The Editorial Board. https://t.co/12qK2NmlFt

The European Union recommended halting nonessential travel from the U.S. because of the rise of Covid-19 cases, diplomats said on Monday, ending a summer vacation reprieve for American tourists https://t.co/UXcycCCAFp
Two broken MacBooks and quotes from four repair shops help columnist @JoannaStern explain why new “Right to Repair” legislation could save you money and time https://t.co/Q74vWcZ3V1
China is cracking down on youth videogame addiction: No gaming during the school week and one hour a day on Fridays, weekends and public holidays https://t.co/1U27vP9IXC

Ida hit Louisiana as a Category 4 hurricane, testing a $14.6 billion system including levees and floodwalls and threatening the Gulf’s vast oil-refining capacity, before being downgraded to a tropical storm on Monday #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/BN5SzwYh0w
GM’s Chevy Bolt recall has become a $1.8 billion headache for the auto maker, highlighting the high cost of fixing defective batteries in electric vehicles https://t.co/dacFJBK8vR
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/vBxwtMKypp https://t.co/VW2rKj19iR
A group of American civilians pieced together a global network in a matter of days to airlift 5,000 people from Kabul. Now they are looking for countries to take them. https://t.co/PwtrZtNLHk
The Department of Health and Human Services is preparing a new office that will treat climate change as a public-health issue https://t.co/EDRKTxHoqq
The European Union is set to recommend halting nonessential travel from the U.S. because of Covid-19, diplomats said https://t.co/AUSTy3NDf4

Gen X and older millennial women are increasingly splurging on multiple earlobe and cartilage piercings. For some, these “ear parties” send a message: “Wait, I’m not just a mom. I’m still young and I’m still cool.” https://t.co/NXeDplD76j
Malaysia is a little-known but critical link in the semiconductor supply chain. A Covid-19 surge there threatens to prolong uncertainty about global chip supply. https://t.co/2MQPYT04w0
North Korea appears to have restarted a plutonium-producing nuclear reactor, inspectors say, a move that could allow the country to expand its weapons stockpile https://t.co/sETh4tFZPj
Burned out and equipped with savings, some millennials are quitting their jobs with no Plan B https://t.co/pVgTsK1zDj
